title: When writing a critique, does a reader first find the central idea and supporting details? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends. There’s no established procedure or format for critique, but if you’re doing a critique for a fiction writer, their expectations will be different from those of a non-fiction writer. In either case, different writers have different expectations, so it’s best to ask them what they’re looking for in your critique. If you’re taking it upon yourself to critique work for some purpose—a review blog or “response” to a work, for example—then all bets are off, and you can choose what you want to focus on. Most works—fiction or not—will have some central idea and supporting details, but it’s not essential to find them first, or to even focus on them in a review, unless that’s what you want to do or what others expect of you.
